animalOfTheDay.name: swordfish
facts: Their sword-like bill is used to slash at prey, stunning or injuring them.
They can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making them one of the fastest fish.
Swordfish have a specialized organ that warms their eyes and brain, improving their vision in cold water.
Swordfish can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet in search of food.

calendar.name: squid
facts: The giant squid is the largest invertebrate, with eyes the size of dinner plates.
Squid have three hearts: two pump blood to the gills, and one pumps it to the rest of the body.
They can change color rapidly to communicate or camouflage, using specialized cells called chromatophores.
Some squid species can 'fly' by propelling themselves out of the water and gliding for short distances.

calendar.name: squirrel
facts: Squirrels plant thousands of trees each year by forgetting where they buried their acorns.
Some species of squirrels can leap up to 20 feet between trees.
They can rotate their ankles 180 degrees to climb down trees headfirst.
Squirrels communicate with each other using tail flicking and vocalizations.

calendar.name: starfish
facts: There are over 2,000 species of starfish, found in all the world's oceans.
Starfish are not fish; they are echinoderms, related to sea urchins and sand dollars.
They can regenerate lost arms, and some species can even regrow an entire body from a single arm.
Starfish have no brain or blood; instead, they use a water vascular system to move their tube feet.

calendar.name: stick insect
facts: Stick insects are among the longest insects, with some species reaching over 2 feet in length.
They can regenerate lost limbs when they molt.
Some species can reproduce without males through parthenogenesis.
Stick insects are masters of camouflage, resembling twigs or leaves.

calendar.name: stingray
facts: Stingrays 'fly' through the water by flapping their pectoral fins like wings.
Stingrays are closely related to sharks and have skeletons made of cartilage, not bone.
They use electroreceptors to detect the electrical signals of prey hidden in the sand.
Their stingers are modified scales and can deliver venom, but they only use them in self-defense.

calendar.name: stoat
facts: Stoats are small but fierce predators that can take down prey much larger than themselves.
In cold climates, they turn white in winter and are called ermine.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting in trees and water.
Stoats perform a hypnotic 'dance' to confuse prey before attacking.

calendar.name: swordfish
facts: Swordfish can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet in search of food.
Swordfish have a specialized organ that warms their eyes and brain, improving their vision in cold water.
Their sword-like bill is used to slash at prey, stunning or injuring them.
They can swim at speeds up to 60 mph, making them one of the fastest fish.

randomAnimals.name: robin
facts: They are one of the first birds to sing at dawn, earning them the nickname 'the early bird.'
Robins sing year-round, with males using song to establish territory and attract mates.
They are territorial and will aggressively defend their feeding areas in winter.
Robins are known for their red breasts, which are brighter in males during breeding season.

randomAnimals.name: wolf
facts: Wolves are large canids and the ancestors of domestic dogs.
They are highly social animals and live in packs.
Wolves are carnivores and hunt large prey.
They are found in North America, Europe, and Asia.

randomAnimals.name: pheasant
facts: Pheasants roost in trees at night to avoid ground predators.
They are ground-dwelling but can fly short distances to escape predators.
Males have elaborate plumage and perform courtship displays to attract females.
Pheasants are colorful birds native to Asia but introduced worldwide for hunting.
